head.title: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other

hedline.hl1: Mideast Turmoil Is Like No Other

abstract.p: Jeremy Sharp letter questions Thomas L Friedman's suggestion (Oct 13) that Yasir Arafat could have settled for Prime Min Ehud Barak's peace offer; contends that Arafat never had domestic support to accept partial compromises

block.p: Thomas L. Friedman's suggestion (column, Oct. 13) that Yasir Arafat could have settled for Prime Minister Ehud Barak's peace offer is based on the faulty assumption that the Palestinian leadership would be politically capable of reaching an agreement that left Israel with ultimate control over Arab parts of Jerusalem.

Thomas L. Friedman's suggestion (column, Oct. 13) that Yasir Arafat could have settled for Prime Minister Ehud Barak's peace offer is based on the faulty assumption that the Palestinian leadership would be politically capable of reaching an agreement that left Israel with ultimate control over Arab parts of Jerusalem.

Yet Mr. Arafat never had the domestic support to accept partial compromises, as logical and desirable as they may seem. We must remember that the peace talks forestalled the discussions of Jerusalem in order to build trust between both sides.

Unfortunately, Israeli and Palestinian sensitivities over Jerusalem have not died down. Until the American public realizes this, we will continue to point fingers in each direction, lamenting the fact that an agreement was almost at hand.
